administrator  5486 division 1  generally secs 2912140  reserved division 2  personnel policies purpose and objectives a purpose the personnel policies in this division are designed to bring to the city service a high degree of understanding cooperation efficiency and unity uniform application of modern personnel practices b objectives the fundamental objectives of good personnel administration sought to be achieved by these policies are to 1 promote and increase efficiency and economy in the service of the city 2 provide fair and equal opportunity to all qualified applicants to enter and advance in city employment on the basis of merit and fitness as ascertained practical methods of selection and promotion without regard to sex race color religion disability age national origin or any other nonmerit factor 3 maintain recruitment advancement and tenure practices enhancing the attractiveness of a city career and encourage each employee to give the employees best effort to the job and the public 4 maintain compensation based upon the relative duties and responsibilities of positions in the service of the city 5 develop high morale among city employees by fostering good working relationships and by providing uniform personnel policies opportunity for advancement and consideration for employee welfare 6 ensure that employees are protected against coercion for partisan political purposes and are prohibited from using their positions with the city for the purpose of interfering with or affecting the results of any kind of official election a applicability the personnel rules in this division apply to all city employees an employee is any person appointed to a position in the city service a person on retainer or under contract is not considered to be a city employee in the absence of a specific agreement to that effect b no contract created the employee handbook is not a contractual agreement written applications for employment statements concerning introductory status as well as the personnel policies do not imply an agreement of contract between the employee and the city the personnel policies are available in the personnel office for inspection and review by all city employees employment with the city may be terminated by the city at any time without liability for wages or salary except such as may have been earned at the date of termination employment with the city is for no definite period of time and the city can change wages benefits and conditions at any time c dissemination all city employees will be informed of the existence of the personnel policies all fulltime employees will be provided a copy of the personnel policies and all amendments and revisions as they are adopted d amendments a the city council may unilaterally change rescind supplement or supersede the personnel rules at any time without notice b the provisions of the personnel rules control over any contradictory statement made by any city supervisor e   11172009 administration and division of responsibility a with the exception of matters reserved to the city council the city manager may change or amend the personnel rules in this division within the law to the extent the city manager deems necessary in order to more effectively and efficiently promote the interest of the city and its employees the director of personnel is authorized and directed to interpret develop and implement necessary procedures and regulations for the efficient administration of these policies b department heads and supervisory personnel are responsible for enforcing the provisions of these policies and for cooperating with the personnel department on all related matters pertinent to their organizational units department heads may adopt supplemental personnel policies procedures and work rules not in conflict with these citywide policies subject to the approval of the city manager or personnel director f   11172009 equal employment opportunity policy it is the employment policy of the city to obtain individuals qualified andor trainable for positions in city service without discrimination based upon race color religion national origin sex age physical or mental disability except when age sex or physical requirements constitute a bona fide occupational qualification necessary for the proper and efficient fulfillment of the job g affirmative action policy a purpose in order to achieve equal employment opportunity with the city a passive prohibition against discrimination is insufficient an affirmative effort is required to create and preserve an environment conducive to equal employment opportunity the city will perform those actions necessary to ensure that discrimination does not and will not exist within its jurisdiction b scope this policy refers without reservation to all recruitment selection and placement training promotions benefits transfers layoffs termination and any other matter affecting employees within the city this policy will be administered to provide employees with the necessary opportunities for growth and advancement on the basis of individual merit ability and capability h sexual harassment policy a policy it is the policy of the city that all employees are entitled to a work environment that is free from sexual intimidation and any unwelcome sexual advances the city prohibits any form of sexual harassment as defined under title vii of the civil rights act of 1964 any employee who engages in any conduct or action which constitutes sexual harassment is subject to disciplinary action up to and including termination b purpose the purpose of this policy is to define sexual harassment and to outline the responsibilities of supervisors and employees when this problem is encountered c definition sexual harassment is defined as unwelcome sexual advances requests for sexual favors and other verbal and physical conduct of a sexual nature when 1 submission to such conduct is made either explicitly or implicitly a term or condition of an individuals employment  2 submission to or rejection of such conduct by an individual is used as the basis of employment decisions affecting such individual  or 3 such conduct has the purpose or effect of unreasonably interfering with an individuals work performance or creating an intimidating hostile or offensive working environment d examples in relation to the definition in subsection c of this section such conduct includes but is not limited to the following 1 repeated offensive sexual flirtations advances or propositions  2 continued or repeated offensive verbal abuse of a sexual nature  3 the display of sexually suggestive objects or pictures  4 any offensive or abusive physical conduct of a sexual nature e procedures any employee who complains in good faith of sexual harassment will be protected against retaliation or reprisal for making the complaint all allegations of sexual harassment shall be maintained in a separate filing system and shall not become a part of the employee files 1 each supervisor is responsible for maintaining the supervisors workplace free of sexual harassment this duty includes discussing this policy and procedure with all employees and ensuring them that they are not required to endure insulting degrading or exploitative sexual treatment 2 any employee who believes that the employee has been the subject of sexual harassment or who knows of such acts within the citys employment should report the alleged act immediately to the employees supervisor should the immediate supervisor be the offending party in a harassment complaint the employee may report to the next level of management or to the personnel department 3 any sexual harassment observed or reported to a supervisor will be immediately investigated and the result of the investigation will be reported chain of command to the department head 4 all activities and actions required to resolve sexual harassment complaints will be conducted by management in order to protect the rights of both complaining and offending parties 5 disciplinary action shall be taken against any employee in violation of this policy such disciplinary action will be determined by the nature of the wrongful act and may result in dismissal 6 if the employee is not satisfied with the action taken by the supervisor the employee may bring the complaint to the attention of the personnel director and follow the normal procedure for filing a grievance as stated in the grievance procedures of the personnel policies f confidentiality all allegations of sexual harassment shall be treated with strict confidence by all parties involved failure to comply with the confidentiality requirement will subject the violator to disciplinary action g note at any time during an investigation an employee feels uncomfortable reporting the details of an incident to a supervisor of the opposite sex the employee will be given the opportunity to report the details to someone of the same sex i employee responsibilities a political activity except as otherwise provided by law the following restrictions on political activity shall apply to city employees 1 city employees may seek election to any public office provided that a mandatory leave is requested approved and taken effective no later than the announcement date for candidacy or the official filing deadline for office whichever comes first and remains on leave until either withdrawing from the contention or until the election is over employees who are elected to salaried public office are required to resign from city employment effective the date they take office 2 no city employee shall circulate petitions or campaign literature for elective city officials or in any way be concerned with soliciting or receiving any subscriptions contributions or political service from any person on behalf of such elective official 3 no employee shall engage in political activities during the employees working hours with the city b solicitations the following restrictions on solicitations shall apply to city employees 1 the city forbids unauthorized requests for money and all other types of solicitation on city property and during an employees work time without the express approval of the city manager 2 the distribution of any unauthorized literature pamphlets or material not related to city operations is prohibited during work time and at all times in work areas 3 no employee shall be required to make any contribution or be penalized or rewarded in any way in connection with the employees employment according to the response to any authorized solicitation c dress code and appearance policy department heads may specify certain uniforms for employees in such departments when appropriate for specific work hygiene or safety d conditions of work conditions of work shall be as follows 1 hours of work the hours during which city offices and departments are open for business shall be determined by the city manager a department head shall implement schedules to meet these general requirements and to provide for other specific requirements of the department the city administrative offices observe regular working hours from  am to  pm monday 2 attendance employees shall be required to be at their places of work in accordance with work schedules established by their department any employee who fails to report leaves the workplace without proper authorization arrives habitually tardy or misuses authorized absences may be subject to disciplinary action including termination 3 absences absenteeism is to be discouraged  however there are occasions when an employee must be absent when these times occur the employee shall notify his supervisor of the situation and follow the prescribed rules regarding the type of absence taken it is the employees responsibility to personally arrange absences directly with the immediate supervisor it will not be acceptable except under emergency conditions to have friends or family members arrange absences nor will it be acceptable to request coworkers to inform the immediate supervisor of absences e use of job title all jobs are designated by job titles on all official records payrolls and communications no job will carry an official title which has not been approved by the city manager as being appropriate to the duties performed f working relationships it shall be the responsibility of employees to perform the duties of their positions at a high level of cooperation efficiency and economy acceptable to their department and the city department heads and supervisors shall plan organize direct and control the work of their units to achieve the objectives of the department including the establishment of performance standards for positions within their jurisdiction  hiring practices a creation and filling of positions all positions and employment in the city service are created for the sole purpose of accomplishing the necessary work program or services of the city as approved in the adopted budget b medical examination after a conditional offer of employment before being appointed each prospective employee is required to undergo a medical examination by a physician designated by the city the cost to be borne by the city any employee desiring to be examined by his private physician may do so at the employees own expense no one who is given a medical examination shall be employed unless the examining physician certifies that the person meets the minimum standards of physical fitness required for the position certain classes of employees may be exempted from this subsection upon approval of the city manager c preemployment drug screening the policy and procedures for preemployment drug screening shall be as follow 1 policy the city will not hire any applicant for employment found to be engaging in the use or consumption of controlled substances or the abuse of alcohol unless such controlled substance is prescribed for the user by a physician and then only if such controlled substance is being usedconsumed for the purpose intended 2 consent all applicants for employment shall be required to consent to and pass a controlled substance screening as a prerequisite to employment 3 failure of screening applicants for employment who do not consent to and pass the required controlled substance screening will not be hired further such applicants for employment will not be reconsidered for employment for a period of 12 months following a failed or refused controlled substance screen 4 confidentiality all preemployment controlled substance screening results shall be the private and confidential property of the city and will not be shared with anyone except the applicant or as required by a court order or to legally protect the city d nepotism the policy for nepotism shall be as follows 1 purpose the purpose of the nepotism policy is to avoid the perception of favoritism and cronyism in government relationships and to prevent conflicts of interest arising as a result of defined relationships between employees 2 policy an applicant shall be ineligible for employment if related within the second degree of affinity marriage or within the third degree of consanguinity blood to the mayor any member of the city council the city manager or assistant city manager this prohibition does not apply to any person continuously employed by the city for a period of two years prior to the election of the mayor or city councilmembers or the appointment of the city manager or assistant city manager 3 supervision no employee may directly or indirectly supervise or be supervised by a member of his immediate family or within the third degree of consanguinity 4 marriagecohabitation any situation in which marriage or cohabitation by employees working in the same department occurs must be rectified by transferring to another department as soon as a position is open for which the individual involved is the most qualified unless an acceptable option is chosen within 120 days the employee with the shorter length of service will be discharged e residence there shall be no absolute residence requirement for city employment except as may be provided by law employees likely to be called to work in cases of emergency may be required to reside within reasonable commuting ranges of their places of work f training policy it is the policy of the city to strive to provide for the necessary training of its employees the type of training provided by the city is of an onthejob nature the city at its own expense may send employees to schools conferences or seminars as these training situations become available    11172009 orientation a orientation period policy every person initially appointed to the city shall be required to successfully complete an orientation period of six months every person promoted in the city service shall be required to successfully complete an orientation period of six months the initial and promotion orientation period provides a specific timeframe for supervisors to monitor evaluate and assist an employee in adjustment to service with the city in general and to the position in particular b purpose department heads and supervisors shall use the orientation period to closely observe and evaluate the work and fitness of employees and to encourage adjustment to their jobs and the city service only those employees who meet acceptable standards during the orientation period shall be retained in their positions c benefits employees will accrue vacation and sick leave during the orientation period orientation employees may however only take sick leave during the orientation period d failure of orientation an employee shall fail orientation when in the judgment of the department head the employees fitness andor quality of work are not such as to merit continuation on the job failure of orientation may occur at any time within the orientation period and shall not be considered part of the disciplinary process  compensation a policy it is the citys policy to provide equitable compensation for its employees in the form of pay and fringe benefits to attract and retain qualified personnel for all positions the compensation that an employee receives from the city is based on a schedule of positions salaries and wages as approved by the city council and contained in the annual budget b job descriptions jobs are distinguished by a written job specification including job title duties and responsibilities and a statement of minimum qualifications necessary for satisfactory performance of the duties of the job c responsibility the personnel office shall be responsible for administration of the pay benefits and job specifications and qualifications the personnel office shall revise existing policies and recommend the revisions as the need arises d continuous study of salary rates upon request of the city manager and periodically as the need arises the personnel office shall prepare an analysis of prevailing rates of pay for similar public and private employment in the area and at large taking into consideration costofliving factors budget effects of various alternative pay plans and other factors which may be pertinent in recommending changes in the plan on the basis of this information the city manager may recommend changes in pay policy or change individual pay rates as necessary to keep the pay current uniform and equitable e method of payment the method of payment shall be as follows 1 pay periods pay periods and dates of payment shall be set by the city manager 2 hourly employees employees employed on a hourly basis are paid weekly on fridays 3 salaried employees employees on a salary will be paid semimonthly on the 15th and the 30th of each month f overtime employees shall work overtime when necessary and only on the prior approval of the department head overtime on any job will be allocated as evenly as possible among all employees the citys policy is to pay overtime 112 times the regular rate for all time worked over 40 hours per week excluding firefighters department heads are not normally paid overtime but are given compensatory time g compensatory time the city prefers to provide compensatory time off in lieu of monetary overtime compensation at a rate of 112 hours of compensatory time for each hour of overtime worked fair labor standards guidelines will be followed for compensatory time accumulation and compensation of overtime department heads and supervisors shall keep employees accumulated compensatory time to a minimum department heads and supervisors may limit amounts of compensatory time accumulated and may schedule compensatory time off for employees upon termination an employee will be paid for accumulated compensatory time at the employees regular rate of pay h christmas bonus policy the city usually provides for a christmas bonus to fulltime employees depending on the restrictions of each years fiscal budget i merit system 1 policy merit pay increases will be based on the results of the performance evaluation and the employees ability and efficiency in performing the employees duties and any additional criteria as determined by the city manager automatic pay increases shall not be provided for seniority or tenure all merit increases may be granted only by the city manager on recommendation of the department head 2 evaluations performance evaluations will be administered twice a year all merit raises are subject to the restrictions of the current fiscal budget j payment of accumulated leave upon termination of employment 1 an employee will be paid for 25 percent of accumulated sick leave to a maximum of 30 days paid if the employee has a minimum of two years of service upon termination of employment and separates in good standing good standing is defined as follows a gives proper notice of termination to the department two weeks b takes only appropriate days off during the last two weeks of employment ie weekends or scheduled days off c turns in all city equipment uniforms etc that have been issued equipment must be in acceptable working condition d termination for violation of city personnel policies standard operating procedure safety policies or excessive absenteeism will not be considered leaving in good standing 2 failure to return cityissued equipment uniforms materials records or other items may result in delay of payment of terminal pay terminal pay may also be delayed due to any pending investigation of an employee    11172009 leave a holiday leave the holiday leave policy shall be as follows 1 municipal offices with the exception of those in emergency categories shall be closed on the following official holidays a new years day b martin luther king day c good friday d memorial day e independence day f labor day g thanksgiving h thanksgiving friday i day before christmas december 24 j christmas day december 25 2 if a regularly scheduled holiday falls on a saturday or sunday the holiday is taken on friday or monday respectively 3 fulltime employees are entitled to paid holidays time regular employees who would normally have worked on the day observed as a holiday are paid for the number of hours they would have worked had the holiday not occurred seasonal employees will receive time off for the holiday without pay 4 an employee who is absent without authorization or who is on leave without pay on the day immediately preceding or following a holiday shall lose pay for the holiday as well as the pay for that day 5 an employee who is on vacation approved military leave or a scheduled nondisciplinary leave of absence when a holiday is observed will be paid the employees regular rate for that holiday 6 all employees who are required to work on holidays shall be given an alternate day off and shall be paid regular rates for the time worked on the holiday 7 holidays falling within an employees vacation period or within a period of absence properly chargeable to illness shall not be counted against vacation or sick leave 8 employees desiring to observe religious holidays not coinciding with official holidays may be given time off without pay or may be authorized to use accrued vacation leave or compensatory time b vacation leave the purpose of and policy for vacation leave is as follows 1 purpose vacation leave is provided for the specific purpose of allowing employees periods of rest and recreation 2 policy all fulltime employees earn vacation from the date of employment vacation is earned according to the following schedule years of service days earned per month days earned per year hours earned per year 05 083 10 80 6 092 11 88 7 100 12 96 8 108 13 104 9 117 14 112 10 125 15 120 a accrued vacation may be used after six months of employment accumulated vacation can be carried forward beyond a calendar year employees with less than ten years service can accumulate a maximum of 21 days or 168 hours of vacation employees with over ten years service can accumulate a maximum of 30 days or 240 hours of vacation when maximum vacation is accumulated the employee does not earn vacation until accumulated vacation is reduced below the maximum b certified individuals employed in either the police or fire department are entitled to 15 vacation days each year with pay if the member has been regularly employed in the department for at least one year c vacation leave may not be taken prior to the completion of six months of employment except in cases of emergency to be determined by the department head d vacation cannot be taken in advance of being earned all vacation leave must be approved in advance by the department head any employee requesting in excess of 15 consecutive working days of vacation leave must have department head and personnel department approval e leave credits are not transferable between employees f seasonal and temporary employees do not earn vacation g time regular employees earn vacation in the proportion that their regularly scheduled work period bears to the regularly scheduled work period of fulltime employees in the same department h leave may be taken in fourhour or halfday increments although employees are encouraged to take vacations in fullweek segments vacations can also be taken in units of half days and whole days i all leave requests must be approved by the department head so that schedules and duties may be adjusted to create minimum disruption of normal work operations except in extraordinary circumstances vacation time must be requested at least one week in advance j holidays falling in the vacation period of the employee will not be counted as part of vacation leave k employees who leave the employment of the city in good standing after serving six months will be paid for their unused vacation time employees terminating prior to six months of service will not be paid for vacation time l employees shall not be allowed to receive pay for accrued vacation in lieu of taking time off m employees may not receive cash payment on accrued vacation except upon termination retirement or death n employees shall not be allowed to borrow vacation time against future accrual o employees who are laterally transferred promoted or demoted shall retain accrued vacation leave p fire department employees who work shifts other than a regular fortyhour week are charged vacation time at the rate of two days per shift c sick leave the purpose of and policy for sick leave is as follows 1 purpose the intent of sick leave is to preclude loss of income for absences due to illness or injury during the employees regular workweek 2 policy all fulltime salaried city employees earn 114 days of sick leave per month or 15 days per year based on their anniversary date sick leave may be accumulated not to exceed 120 days a fulltime hourly employees earn five days of sick leave per year b fire department employees who work shifts other than a regular 40hour week are charged sick leave time at the rate of two days for one shift c during the orientation period sick leave shall accumulate and may be used d sick leave may not be used in advance of being earned e sick leave credits are not transferable between employees f employees may use vacation time in lieu of sick leave g when absence due to illness exceeds the amount of paid leave earned and authorized the pay of an employee shall be discontinued until he returns to work h employees who are laterally transferred promoted or demoted shall retain accrued sick leave i employees can use sick leave for medical dental or ocular appointments  personal illness  or physical incapacity j to receive sick leave the employee must notify his immediate supervisor within the time limits established by the department k failure to ensure proper notification without a valid reason shall constitute absence without leave l no city employee shall be entitled to sick leave while absent from duty on account of the following causes 1 disability arising from any sickness or injury purposely inflicted or caused by willful misconduct 2 sickness or disability sustained while on leave of absence without pay 3 ordinary tiredness or restlessness 4 disability acquired as a result of another job m a department head may require an employee to take sick leave when evidence exists that an employee is ill or injured and where the department head believes the employees medical condition may pose a personal hazard or impose risk to others n employees who are absent for more than three successive days of unconfirmed illness may be required by the department head to submit a physicians statement an employee who consistently uses sick leave as it accumulates may be required to submit a physicians statement for any claimed illness or injury causing an absence from work for more than half a day o an employee who misuses sick leave may be subject to disciplinary action up to and including dismissal p an employee will be paid for 25 percent of accumulated sick leave a maximum of 30 days paid if the employee has a minimum of two years of service upon termination of employment the employee must separate or resign in good standing d family medical leave act the purpose of and policy for family medical leave is as follows 1 purpose the family medical leave act fmla requires covered employers to provide up to 12 weeks of unpaid jobprotected leave to eligible employees for certain family and medical reasons employees are eligible if they have worked at least one year and for 1250 hours over the previous 12 months 2 reasons for taking family medical leave unpaid family medical leave will be granted for any of the following reasons a to care for the employees child after birth or placement for adoption or foster care b to care for the employees spouse son or daughter or parent who has a serious health condition c for a serious health condition that makes the employee unable to perform the employees job any accumulated leave sick vacation compensatory etc will be used in lieu of unpaid leave 3 advance notice and medical certification employees will be required to provide advance leave notice and medical certification taking of leave may be denied if requirements are not met a the employee ordinarily must provide 30 days advance notice when the leave is foreseeable b the city may require medical certification to support a request for leave because of a serious health condition and may require second or third opinions at the employers expense and a fitness for duty report to return to work 4 job benefits and protection a for the duration of family medical leave act leave the city will maintain the employees health coverage b upon return from family medical leave act leave most employees will be restored to their original or equivalent positions with equivalent pay benefits and other employment terms c the use of family medical leave act leave cannot result in the loss of any employment benefit that accrued prior to the start of an employees leave e emergencybereavement leave the purpose of and policy for emergency and bereavement leave is as follows 1 purpose emergency leave is designed to minimize the need for fulltime employees to use vacation leave or compensatory time in cases involving death or illness in the employees immediate family or household 2 policy any full or parttime employee may be granted emergency leave with pay by the employees department head in case of illness or death of members of the immediate family seasonal employees may be granted unpaid leave such leave will not exceed five working days in a 12month period to any employee this leave does not count against sick leave or vacation time 3 restrictions immediate family is restricted to the following a spouse b child natural step adopted c mother d father e brother f sister g grandmother h grandfather i aunt j uncle k fatherinlaw l motherinlaw m brotherinlaw n sisterinlaw o daughterinlaw p soninlaw q more distant relative residing in the home of the employee f funeral leave policy leave for attendance of funerals not provided under emergency leave may be granted heads not to exceed two days per calendar year g military leave policy military leave will be granted in accordance with state and federal laws h court leave the policy for court leave is as follows 1 pay continued employees called upon for jury service will receive their regular salary from the city during such services 2 enforcement officers court appearances as a city enforcement officer fire police inspections etc are compensated as actual hours worked and are not classified as paid leave 3 witness an employee directed to appear as a witness for the city the state or the federal government will be compensated for the employees time as stated in subsection h1 or 2 of this section 4 documentation required an employee summoned either for jury duty or as a witness must provide an official certificate of attendance to the employees immediate supervisor 5 personal legal business an employee absent for personal legal business must use accrued vacation or compensatory time leave without pay may be used with the department heads approval i civic leave  time off to vote employees are encouraged to register to vote it is the responsibility of the employee to contact his immediate supervisor regarding choosing a time to vote the supervisor may select another time if the chosen time conflicts with departmental duties the supervisor however must give sufficient time to the employee to exercise his right to vote j career enrichment leave career enrichment leave may be granted as follows 1 with the approval of the city manager a department head may grant an employee administrative absence with pay for purposes of attending a professional conference convention training activity legislative proceeding or civic function or meeting or for purposes of coordinating with governmental andor private agencies and entities in the interest of the city 2 all employees in the city service shall be entitled to necessary time off with pay for the purpose of taking qualifying or promotional examinations for other positions within the city service the amount of time allowed for this activity shall be limited as prescribed by the city manager k leave of absence without pay a leave of absence without pay may be granted as follows 1 restrictions department heads with the approval of the director of personnel may grant leaves of absence without pay to regular employees not to exceed 30 days in duration in granting such leave the department head shall give primary consideration to the citys need for the employees services a leave of absence without pay may be granted for any legitimate purpose such as absence for illness disability and pregnancy  however the employee will be obligated to show that the granting of such leave is to the interest of the city a leave of absence without pay in excess of 30 days may be granted only with the approval of the city manager and in no case shall the leave exceed six months 2 request of leave any employee requesting a leave of absence without pay must submit a written request to his department head at least two weeks prior to the date upon which the requested leave is to begin the employee is responsible for keeping the department informed of his intention andor ability to work 3 limitations a department head may revoke a leave of absence if the cause for granting leave was misrepresented or has ceased to exist an employee who takes time off without the approval of the employees department head or otherwise fails to return to work on the date designated is subject to disciplinary action including termination 4 insurance coverage an employee on unpaid leave of absence will pay for the employees dependents coverage and any premium for the employees own coverage that the city does not currently pay an employee must make arrangements to pay the costs of the coverage with the personnel department an employees failure to make payments to the city on a timely basis will result in the insurance being discontinued 5 disciplinary actions employees on disciplinary suspension without pay may not use compensatory vacation or sick leave to recuperate the lost time 6 reinstatement during an employees approved leave of absence without pay the employees vacant position may be filled temporarily or permanently by appointment promotion or reassignment of an employee at the expiration of leave without pay the employee may be reinstated to the position the employee vacated if the position still exists and if the position has not been filled if the position has been filled the employee may apply for any vacant position with the city 1 health and safety a safety all employees are required as a condition of employment to exercise due care in the course of work to prevent or minimize injuries to the employee and the employees coworkers and to protect and conserve city equipment each employee shall 1 obey all safety rules regulations and policies published in the employee safety handbook 2 report to the employees immediate supervisor all unsafe work conditions 3 keep work areas clean and orderly at all times 4 report immediately all accidents in which the employee is involved to the employees immediate supervisor 5 operate only machines or equipment that the employee has been authorized to operate employees who defy safety procedures or display gross negligence which may or may not cause damage to property or injury to others will be subject to disciplinary action b onthejob injuryaccident reporting each employee is required to report any and all accidents no matter how slight to his supervisor at once all supervisors are to report such accidents to the personnel office at the time an accident is reported to the personnel office an accident report will be completed in full c workers compensation 1 supervisor responsibility all onthejob injuries and illnesses regardless of how minor are to be reported on the city of nacogdochesreport of injury form available in each department the immediate supervisor of the injured employee will complete the form and forward it department head to the personnel department the same day the accident occurs if a jobrelated disability injury results in lost time the personnel department should be notified immediately of the date the employee begins losing time the personnel department should also be notified immediately of the date the employee returns to work failure to advise the personnel department of the status of the injured employee may result in a delay of the employee receiving workers compensation payment 2 employee responsibility an employee who suffers an occupational injury or illness shall report the incident to his immediate supervisor within 24 hours after it occurs any employee who is physically able but does not meet this reporting requirement shall not be eligible for injured employee compensation during the initial week of disability see subsection c3b of this section 3 compensation is given in accordance with the following a an employee who suffers a disabling losttime occupational injury or illness is eligible for workers compensation benefits in accordance with the provisions of the law b an employee authorized to be off duty due to an occupational injury or illness shall be paid injured employee compensation by the city for a maximum of five workdays at the regular rate of pay during the first week of disability to be eligible for injured employee compensation an employee must 1 if physically able report the injury to his supervisor within 24 hours 2 endorse any workers compensation checks for the initial five workdays to the city c after the initial week of disability an employee is eligible to receive weekly workers compensation payments subject to minimum and maximum payments an employee with accrued sick leave may elect to receive sick leave payments which is chargeable against the employees accrued sick leave and when added to the workers compensation shall equal the employees regular pay d an employee who remains disabled after using all available sick leave will continue receiving workers compensation payments in accordance with the provisions of law 4 an employee authorized to be off duty due to an occupational injury or illness shall continue to earn vacation and sick leave at the regular rate 5 the attending physician should complete the city of nacogdoches doctors medical report at the time of treatment and return the report to the department head of the employee the department head shall adhere to the physicians instructions in the report and forward the report to the personnel department 6 the department head shall initiate the supplemental report of injury form and submit it to the personnel department within 24 hours of any action such as a the employee returns to work from losttime injury b the injured employee has not returned to work after 60 consecutive days  and each subsequent 60day period thereafter c the employee loses additional time because of the original injury d the injury was initially reported as no lost time but subsequent to that report the employee begins to lose time because of the injury 7 an employee authorized to be off duty due to an occupational injury and who violates the following shall be subject to disciplinary action including dismissal if the employee a is found to be working part time or full time either for pay or otherwise for himself or another employer  b falsifies or misrepresents his physical condition or disability as worse than it in fact is  c consistently fails or refuses to follow the instructions of the treating physician  or d refuses to return to regular duty or perform light duty when authorized by the treating physician and offered such duty by the department head d controlled substance and alcohol abuse the city acknowledges that its success now as well as in the future is dependent upon the physical and psychological wellbeing of its employees accordingly it is the citys right obligation and intent to maintain a safe working environment for all of its employees  to protect city property equipment and operations  and to fulfill its obligation to the general public the policy purpose and procedures for controlled substance and alcohol abuse are as follows 1 policy the manufacture distribution use or possession by an employee of an intoxicating liquor controlled substance drug not medically authorized or any other substance which may impair job performance or pose a hazard or serious risk to the safety and welfare of the employee fellow employees the city or general public whether on or off the job shall constitute cause for disciplinary action up to and including termination 2 scope this policy applies to all employees of the city this policy also applies to all applicants for employment with the city 3 purpose the manufacture distribution possession use or consumption of controlled substances or alcohol or being under the influence of controlled substances or alcohol may create serious risk for the involved employee fellow employees the city and the general public this policy is to assist in the reduction of such risks 4 testing of employees current employees may be tested for controlled substances or alcohol use under the following circumstances a if an accident occurs on the job or on city property b when an employees behavior or work performance gives reasonable cause to believe the employee is affected by the use or ingestion of controlled substances or alcohol c to comply with local state federal government laws ordinances or regulations 5 failure of test a current employee failing a controlled substance and alcohol screen required in accordance with this policy is subject to disciplinary action up to and including discharge 6 refusal of consent an employee who refuses to undergo a controlled substance andor alcohol screening in accordance with this policy shall be treated as if the employee failed the required test e employee assistance for alcohol or drug dependency it is the citys desire to provide assistance to those employees who voluntarily request assistance with a personal alcohol or drug dependency problem employees are responsible for acknowledging their substance abuse problem and for seeking and accepting counseling or rehabilitation assistance before it impairs their performance or conduct and jeopardizes their employment employees who need to enter into a substance abuse treatment program will be allowed to enter a cityapproved program one time without endangering their jobs provided they follow all prescribed treatment programs time off without pay may be authorized in accordance with the citys personnel policy on leaves of absence if needed up to 30 days in most cases participating employees will be returned to their former or comparable position if feasible when treatment is successfully completed some of the costs of the treatment may be covered by the citys health insurance plan continued employment is contingent on the employees participating in any nonwork followup counseling or aftercare treatment programs the personnel director will be the employee assistance program representative and should be contacted in regard to an employees participation in an approved treatment program 2 use of city tools equipment and property a the city attempts to provide each employee with adequate tools equipment and vehicles for the city job being performed and expects each employee to observe safe work practices and safe and courteous operation of vehicles and equipment in compliance with all municipal county and state regulations b employees who are assigned tools or equipment or vehicles by their departments are responsible for them and for their proper use no personal use of any city property materials supplies tools equipment or vehicles is permitted unless authorized by the department head or city manager c if an employee is found to have used any city vehicle or equipment in a negligent manner and such vehicle or equipment becomes destroyed or damaged the employee may be subject to disciplinary action 3 discipline a purpose the purpose of discipline is to produce a change in the behavior of an employee so that the individuals future conduct complies with city policies and supports the attainment of the organizations objectives discipline should be used to correct unsatisfactory behavior and to encourage more effective performance in disciplining employees emphasis will be placed on correctionnot on punishment for the sake of punishment b grounds disciplinary action may be taken against an employee for just cause the following list is by way of example only and is not exhaustive of what actions constitute just cause 1 illegal unethical abusive or unsafe acts 2 violation of city or departmental rules regulations policies or procedures 3 insubordination 4 neglect or abandonment of duties 5 abuse of illness injury disability or other benefits 6 tardiness or absence without leave 7 falsification of official documents or records 8 using or being under the influence of drugs or intoxicating beverages on the job 9 waste damage or unauthorized use of city property or supplies 10 unauthorized use or disclosure of official information 11 unauthorized or improper use of official authority 12 inability to get along with fellow workers 13 discourtesy to the public 14 acceptance of any gratuity or gift for the performance or nonperformance of official duties 15 engaging in horseplay or scuffling on the job 16 fighting or provoking or instigating a fight on city property 17 sleeping on the job during working hours 18 an accumulation of infractions 19 poor work performance 20 any other conduct the city manager department head or a supervisor believes to be inappropriate c disciplinary action violations of the citys rules and procedures or any other misconduct will result in appropriate disciplinary action appropriate disciplinary action will depend upon the circumstances and may include such things as oral warnings written reprimands suspensions probation or discharge d responsibility department heads are responsible for enforcing and maintaining proper standards of discipline and personal conduct among their employees in implementing the disciplinary procedures a department headsupervisor should consider such factors as the type and severity of the offense the employees performance record and any mitigating circumstances surrounding the offense all regular employees have the right to appeal a disciplinary action grievance process e documentation department heads shall submit documentation of any disciplinary actions and the surrounding circumstances to the personnel director for the inclusion in the official personnel files of the employee involved any disciplinary action taken should be documented in writing indicating 1 the cause of discipline 2 the specific reason supporting the cause 3 the discipline to be imposed 4 the effective date 5 the employees right to appeal 4 separations a resignation the policy and procedures for resignation from the city are as follow 1 policy to resign in good standing an employee shall submit a resignation preferably in writing to the department head two weeks before the effective date of the resignation 2 procedure a brief signed statement identifying the effective date of the resignation is adequate an employee may give reasons for resigning but it is not necessary the city manager may waive any portion of the notice period unauthorized absence from work for a period of three working days shall be considered as a resignation 3 benefits a employees who leave the citys employment after serving six months will be paid for their unused vacation time employees terminating prior to six months service will not be paid for vacation time b employees will be paid for 25 percent of accumulated sick leave a maximum of 30 days paid if the employee has a minimum of two years of service upon termination of employment and separates in good standing b layoff policy an employee may be laid off because of changes in duties of the organization or for lack of work or funds whenever possible an employee laid off from one city department shall be transferred to a suitable position elsewhere 5 complaints  grievances a disciplinary and termination policy the citys disciplinary and termination policy is as follows 1 it is the intent of the disciplinary and termination procedure to safeguard the rights of all employees to ensure that all employees are judged by fair and equitable standards and to require that all rules are applied on an equitable basis 2 in the interest of good discipline and efficiency a department head may demote an employee suspend an employee without pay or terminate an employee all demotions suspensions or terminations shall be approved by the personnel director prior to action being taken 3 before an employee may be reclassified with a reduction in pay suspended from employment or terminated the employee shall be notified in writing of the reason for the action and given an opportunity for a hearing before the department head and personnel director at the hearing the employee is entitled to examine evidence cross examine witnesses or present proof 4 when an employee receives written notice of reduction in pay suspension from employment or termination the employee may request a hearing with the department head and personnel director within three working days of receipt of the written notice if a hearing is requested a date and time will be set by the personnel director failure of the employee to request a hearing by the specified time shall waive the rights to determination of any employment dispute and shall constitute consent to any employment action proposed or indicated in the original notice letter 5 at the conclusion of the hearing or as soon as possible thereafter the personnel director and department head shall make a determination and shall make a written report of the hearing and determination 6 the employee may appeal the determination made by the personnel director and department head by delivering a signed written notice within five working days of receipt of the decision to the personnel director a date and time shall be set for the appeal to be heard by the city manager the city manager may request the presence of the personnel director department head and any other persons with knowledge or witness to the cause for action the decision of the city manager will be final 7 an employee may be suspended during an investigation of misconduct in accordance with the following a a regular employee may be suspended with pay subject to reinstatement where applicable where the department head determines that the risk of loss to the city of his continued employment or the critical necessity of public confidence in his integrity requires such suspension b the conclusion of any investigation and termination or reinstatement of any employee shall take place within 60 days of any suspension unless the employee consents directly or by implication to a longer period of suspension b termination processing procedures for termination are as follows 1 it will be the responsibility of the terminating department to ensure that all city property ie keys tools equipment etc has been turned in prior to submitting the exit checklist to the personnel office 2 terminating employees are responsible for completing an exit interview form prior to their last date of employment this form may be obtained in the personnel office employees wishing to talk with the personnel director prior to their effective date of termination may do so by calling the personnel office to schedule an appointment c grievance policy the grievance policy is as follows 1 a grievance is defined as something that causes distress or gives reason to complain grievances relate to working conditions and situations which the employee feels are unfair 2 employees are encouraged to handle all differences of opinion at their department level by bringing the matter to their supervisor immediately if the discussion with the immediate supervisor produces unsatisfactory results the employee may submit a written grievance to the department head if the employee is still unsatisfied if the decision of the department head is not satisfactory the employee shall within five working days of receiving a written decision request from the personnel director a hearing before the city grievance committee 3 the city grievance committee will consist of three staff members selected by the personnel director the grievant for good cause may request substitution of one of the three chosen committee members the decision to substitute any member shall be at the discretion of the personnel director 4 the grievance committee shall hold an informal meeting at which all parties shall have the opportunity to present their case to ascertain the facts surrounding the grievance the committee shall make a written report and render a recommendation to the city manager within five working days of the hearing the city manager shall review the recommendations of the grievance committee and provide a final written response to the grievant the decision of the city manager shall be final 6 performance evaluations a purpose the performance appraisals are designed to help supervisory personnel and employees measure how well city work is being performed and to provide a tool for management decisions regarding training assignment promotion salary adjustment and retention of city employees b evaluation the work performance of each employee shall be evaluated in accordance with procedures developed by the personnel department special evaluations may be made if requested by the department head and in those departments where applicable performance appraisals should be administered twice annually all performance appraisals shall be completed on standardized forms provided by the personnel department c counseling an employee should sign copies of the employees own performance appraisal reports evaluators shall individually discuss the reports with the employee and shall counsel the employee regarding the job performance and any improvements in such performance which appear desirable or necessary d reconsideration an employee dissatisfied with the performance appraisal may seek reconsideration chain of command to the employees department head e records all performance appraisals shall become a permanent part of the employees personnel file maintained in the personnel department 7 employee records a official personnel file the personnel department shall maintain the official personnel file for all city employees it is the responsibility of supervisors to ensure that all necessary documentation is forwarded to the personnel department for inclusion in the employees file the personnel director is responsible for ensuring documents of an evaluative or negative nature clearly indicate the employee is aware of the document prior to placement in the employees file the personnel director shall determine the appropriateness of placement of documents in an employees personnel file b employee privacy the director of personnel shall establish procedures necessary to preserve the privacy of employee information as required by applicable state and federal legislation access to privileged or confidential employee records shall be based on the need to know as determined by the personnel director the texas open records act permits an employee or official of a governmental body to dictate whether the public shall have access to the employees home address and telephone number by submitting a written notice to the personnel director no employees home address and telephone number may be disclosed to the public if the employee or city official requests that the items be closed c personnel file review an employee at all times has a right to inspect any and all inclusions made a part of the employees personnel records and may at any time submit personal workrelated information that may be included into his official records d currency of records employees shall notify their supervisor who shall notify the personnel department on the appropriate forms of any change in the following 1 address 2 telephone number 3 person to notify in case of accident or illness 4 nameor otherwise 5 marital status 6 number of dependents 7 insurance beneficiary 8 military status 9 expiration of licenses andor certificates necessary to do the job 8 secs 21622200  reserved article iv  boards committees and commissions footnotes  4  cross reference airport 8299  collection of large dead animals  82100  horsedrawn carriages  110306 et seq article i  general provisions division 1  generally purpose the purpose of this chapter is to a prevent hazards to the physical and mental health of the public caused by animals  b prevent cruelty to animals  c decrease the number of unwanted and stray dogs and cats in the city  d encourage responsible animal ownership  e place the responsibility of complying with its requirements upon an animals owner  definitions abandon means the act of leaving an animal 1 without food water or care for 24 hours or more  or 2 in a situation where conditions present an immediate direct and serious threat to the life safety or health of the animal altered means incapable of reproduction  synonym of sterilized neutered or spayed animal means any warm or coldblooded vertebrate animal control officer means the person designated by the city manager to represent and act for the city in the impoundment of animals controlling of animals running at large and as otherwise provided and required in this chapter  as well as that persons subordinates and designees animal shelter means a facility designated or recognized by the city for the purpose of impounding and caring for animals at large means to be free of physical restraint beyond the boundaries of owners premises companion animal means dogs and cats dangerous dog means any dog that 1 makes an un provoked attack on a person that causes bodily injury and occurs in a place other than an enclosure in which the dog was being kept and that was reasonably certain to prevent the dog from leaving the enclosure on its own  or 2 commits unprovoked acts in a place other than an enclosure in which the dog was being kept and that was reasonably certain to prevent the dog from leaving the enclosure on its own and those acts cause a person to reasonably believe that the dog will attach and cause bodily injury to that person domestic animal includes livestock and normal household pets such as but not limited to dogs cats cockatiels ferrets hamsters guinea pigs gerbils rabbits fish or small non poisonous reptiles or nonpoisonous snakes dumping means to knowingly desert forsake or absolutely give up any dog cat or other companion animal in any public place including the rightofway of any public highway road or street or on the property of another euthanasia means the humane destruction of a companion domestic or exotic animal by a method which causes immediate unconsciousness without visible evidence of distress on the part of the animal exotic animal means any animal not defined as a companion animal or a domestic animal feral cat means a cat too unsocialized to be handled or placed in a typical pet home guard dog or attack dog means any dog intended to attack intruders harboring means the act of keeping and caring for an animal or providing premises to which the animal returns for all or part of three consecutive days inhumane treatment of animals means any treatment of an animal prohibited by any provision of law including federal state and local laws ordinances or rules kennel means any place or premises wherein any person boards breeds buys lets for hire trains for a fee trades or sells dogs or cats  does not include veterinary hospitals or humane societies limited breeder means any person that breeds or allows his or her animal whether purebred or mixed breed to produce offspring livestock means domestic animals generally used or raised on a farm for profit work or pleasure including but not limited to cattle cows sheep pigs bulls stallions mare gelding jack jennies hogs goats llamas ostriches and emus managed feral cat colony means a colony of feral cats in which ttvarm trap test vaccinate alter return monitormanage is being performed cats are altered vaccinated for rabies and eartipped before return to the original location multiple pet owners mean a person who keeps or harbors more than five dogs or five cats or any combination of five cats and dogs one litter of puppies or kittens under four months of age may be excluded from the count owner means any person who has a right of property over an animal keeps or harbors an animal has an animal in hisher care acts as custodian of an animal or permits an animal to remain on or about hisher premises restraint an animal shall be considered under restraint if it is confined to its owners premises by a physical fence in a manner that will isolate the animal from the public and from other animals except for animals owned or under the control of the owner  or is secure by a leash and properly fitted collar  or is otherwise under the physical control of the owner or of another responsible person secure enclosure shall mean a fenced area or structure that is 1 locked  2 capable of preventing the release or escape of an animal  3 capable of preventing the entry of the general public including children  4 clearly marked as containing a dangerous animal by posting signs bearing letters not less than two inches high on all sides of the enclosure  5 is tall enough or covered so that the animal cannot climb out  and 6 has a perimeter structure which prevents the animal from digging out or going under the side fence or wall serious bodily injury means an injury characterized by severe bite wounds or severe ripping and tearing of muscle that would cause a reasonably prudent person to seek treatment from a medical professional and which would require hospitalization without regard to whether the person actually sought medical treatment shelter means a structure that protects animals from the elements it must be enclosed on at least three sides and have a roof and a floor unprovoked attack means an attack or act by an animal which took place even though the person or animal attacked did nothing to cause or encourage the attack or act vaccination means an injection of rabies vaccine approved by the united states department of agriculture and administered in accordance with state law wild animal means those animals of wild nature or disposition so as to require to be reclaimed and made tame by art industry or education or else must be kept in confinement to be brought within the immediate control of the owner    division 2  enforcement impoundment authority generally it shall be the duty of the animal control authority or duly licensed peace officer to carry out all applicable provisions of this chapter and to pick up and impound all animals found to be in violation of this chapter  authority to use tranquilizer equipment in the performance of hisher duties the animal control officers shall have authority to employ tranquilizer equipment and all other animal control devices commonly used by other animal control agencies located within the state of texas  interference it shall be unlawful for any person to interfere with hinder or molest any animal control officer in the performance of any duty delegated under this chapter or seek to release any animal taken and held in custody under provisions of this chapter  notice of impoundment the animal control officer shall at once notify the owner if known of any animal currently in impound pursuant to this chapter the notice shall give a description of the animal impounded including any marks or brands  injured animals animals injured on public property may be impounded and given adequate veterinary medical treatment pending notification of the owner if an injured animal is treated or impounded the owner of such animal shall be liable for all expenses of treatment andor impoundment  however disposition may be made at the discretion of the animal control officer  redemption of impounded animals the owner of any impounded animal may reclaim the animal by signing any citations issued for alleged violations of this chapter and paying all impoundment fees fines and other accrued expenses under following conditions 1 if the owner of any impounded animal pursuant to this chapter shall appear to claim the animal within three business days of notice of impoundment the animal control officer shall if heshe reasonably believes that such person is the true owner turn such animal over to such person upon payment to the animal control officer of a fee for each day that such animal has been impounded the fees shall be collected by the animal control officer and remitted to the city finance department 2 the animal control officer shall upon impoundment attempt to call the owner of any impounded dog or cat that is identified by a collar or harness with the citys registration tag attached or by an implanted microchip 3 if the impounded animal is a dog or cat that is not identified by wearing a collar with a valid license tag attached or by a duly registered implanted microchip the owner of the dog or cat must present a certificate showing that the dog or cat has been vaccinated in accordance with state law from that date or shall have the dog or cat vaccinated prior to its release from impoundment and must provide or secure a valid license for such dog or cat the license tag is to be attached to the dog or cats collar  disposal of unredeemed impounded animals the animal control officer shall have authority to dispose of in accordance with state law all animals impounded in animal shelter 1 any person wishing to adopt an impounded animal shall pay appropriate fees the prospective owner shall be required to have any dog or cat altered properly vaccinated and licensed at hisher own expense 2 the animal control officer may sell the animal impounded and remit the proceeds to city finance department  destruction of impounded animals if no purchaser or owner can be found for any animal impounded pursuant to this section the animal control officer is authorized to humanely destroy such animal and to have the carcass destroyed  records and reports of animal control officer the animal control officer shall record a description of all animals impounded by himher pursuant to this chapter record shall show date of impoundment return to owner or of sale  the name of owner if known  and name of purchaser or adopter  division 3  rabies control suspicion of rabies when person bitten a if any dog or other animal has bitten any person the owner of the animal shall immediately and in any event not later than 24 hours after such biting notify an animal control officer of such biting and have the dog or other animal quarantined according to the discretion of an animal control officer in the city animal shelter or a veterinary hospital in the city or in the home of the owner for a period ten days no such animal so held for observation shall be released from impoundment without authorization from the animal control department such impoundment shall be at the expense of the owner of the animal b if however at the time of the biting the dog or other animal was duly licensed properly identified and was lawfully restrained as required by article iii of this chapter expense of confinement shall be against the person so bitten if such person is on the premises with express or implied consent of the owner such as delivery persons guests post office personnel utility meter readers etc cost of confinement shall be at owners expense  suspicion of rabies when animal bitten a the owner of any dog or other animal suffering a bite from a rabid animal or suspected or believed to have been bitten by a rabid animal shall within 24 hours from the time of such biting notify an animal control officer and have the dog or other animal administered proper treatment or destroyed b when the owner desires to have proper treatment administered to the animal confinement shall be under the direction and supervision of an animal control officer who shall direct the manner and means by which the dog or other animal shall be confined confinement to be for a period of at least ten days and at owners expense c such dog or other animal shall be released only by order of an animal control officer  article ii  care of animals proper care every owner or other person having care and control of any animal shall provide following for each animal under his or her care and control 1 sufficient nutritious and wholesome food served to the animal in clean containers to maintain the animal in good health  2 clean potable water served to the animal in a clean container such water to be available to the animal at all times  3 adequate shelter and protection from weather at all times  4 veterinary care as needed to prevent suffering  inhumane treatment in general prohibited it shall be unlawful for any person to treat any animal in any manner that causes or permits unjustified or unwarranted pain or suffering including torturing an animal beating an animal or overworking an animal  abandonment it is a violation of this chapter for any person to dump or abandon any animal on any property whether public or private within the city of nacogdoches  animals in vehicles a it shall be unlawful to leave an animal in a vehicle under such conditions or for such period of time as may endanger the health or wellbeing of such animal due to heat cold lack of food or water or such other circumstances as may reasonably be expected to cause suffering disability or death b it shall be unlawful for any person to transport or convey any animal in an open vehicle without making provisions to prevent said animal from jumping from or being thrown from said vehicle or conveyance or being otherwise injured  tethering  restrictions and requirements a no unattended animal shall be tethered by any means on any public property such as city parks or utility easements or public access private property without property owners consent b any tethered animal in an enclosure shall have continuous access to shade and water and have unrestricted access to a wind and moisture proof shelter c any tethered animal shall be arranged so that the tethering device cannot become entangled in such a way as to prevent access to shade water and shelter d the tether used must be at least ten feet in length or five times the length of the dog as measured from the tip of the dogs nose to the base of the dogs tail whichever is greater  it must be attached to a running line pulley or trolley system and equipped with swivel ends positioned in such a manner as to prevent the animal from becoming entangled with any obstruction from partially or totally jumping any fence or from leaving any part of its owners property and must be secured to the animal using a properly fitted collar or harness e choke type pinch type or prong type collars may not be used to tether the animal  state law reference vtca health and safety et seq fighting fighting paraphernalia prohibited a it is unlawful to cause any animal to fight with another b it shall be unlawful for any person to keep or use or in any way be connected with or interested in the management of any place used for the purpose of fighting animals it shall be unlawful for any person to receive money for the admission of any person to any place kept or used for the purpose of fighting animals or to permit or suffer any place belonging to or under his control to be so kept or used it shall be unlawful for any person to aid encourage assist or arrange for an animal to fight or to issue a challenge for the purpose of bringing about an animal fight c it shall be unlawful for any person to have on their person or property any paraphernalia used in fighting d it shall be unlawful for any person to raise breed maintain or harbor any animal which is used or intended to be used for fighting  trapping it shall be unlawful for any person to place or set any trap or to trap any animal by any form of trap other than a humane live cage trap as specifically authorized by the animal control department any trap placed or set in violation of this chapter shall be impounded by the animal control officer or the police  tripping of horses prohibited it is unlawful to trip a horse  sanitation a it shall be unlawful for any person to maintain any pen enclosure pound or area for any animal in a manner that is a nuisance or threat to the health or safely of the public b the keeper of any pen shall be responsible for pickup and disposal of all animal feces found in such pen feces must be removed often enough so that there is no odor or fly attraction which would disturb a person of normal sensibilities or to constitute a health hazard to humans or animals  running at large a no animal shall be allowed to run at large and cause a nuisance the owner of every animal shall be held responsible for every behavior of such animal under provisions of this chapter b an animal shall be considered a nuisance if it damages soils defiles or defecates on private property other than the owners or on public walks and recreation areas unless such waste is immediately removed and properly disposed of by the owner  causes unsanitary dangerous or offensive conditions  causes a disturbance by excessive barking or other noisemaking  or chases vehicles or molests attacks or interferes with persons or other domestic animals on public property or private property other than that of the owner  animal in heat any person who owns harbors or keeps any female dog or cat shall during the period such animal is in heat keep such dog or cat in a secured area and in such a manner as to prevent a male dog or cat from having access to such female except for controlled breeding permitted by the owner of the female additionally the female dog or cat shall not be restrained in a manner that prevents her from defending herself or from avoiding a male  secs 625629  reserved article iii  dogs and cats dogs and unaltered cats under restraint dogs and unaltered cats must be under restraint at all times  rabies vaccination required every owner of a dog or cat four months of age or older shall have such animal vaccinated against rabies in accordance with state law any person moving into the city from a location outside the city shall comply with this chapter within ten days after having moved into the city  license required every resident that owns or harbors a dog or cat within the corporate limits shall obtain a license for the animal from the city participating veterinarians may issue city license upon administering rabies vaccine veterinarians may retain $100 for each city license issued and shall remit said license fees to the city on a monthly basis providing description and name of the animal license number name of animal owner address and phone number 1 dog and cat licenses shall be issued by the city upon payment of the license fee and presentation of a properly completed application for license and a certificate from a licensed veterinarian showing that the dog or cat has been vaccinated for rabies and that the vaccination is current according to state law animals less than four months and 30 days or age are exempt the application for dog or cat licenses shall be upon printed forms furnished by the city for such purpose and shall require a name address phone number and email address if available of the owner  and b name breed and sex of the dog or cat  and c the number of any implanted microchip for a dog or cat that is not registered or reregistered within ten days from the expiration date of the license or when otherwise required a date of issuance 4 tag upon compliance by the owner of a dog or cat with registration and licensing requirements of this chapter the owner shall be issued a license certificate and a metallic tag for each dog or cat so licensed 5 duplicates if a dog or cat tag is lost or destroyed a duplicate will be issued by the city upon presentation of a receipt showing payment of the license fee for current
